dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Wikipedia
dataObjects.title: Tanganyika lates
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: "Tanganyika lates." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 1 Mar 2013, 13:36 UTC. 25 Jan 2014 <http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tanganyika_lates&oldid=587466812>.
dataObjects.description:
Lates angustifrons, the Tanganyika lates, is a species of lates perch endemic to Lake Tanganyika. It is a widespread predator on other fishes. This species can reach a length of 200 centimetres (79 in) SL and the greatest recorded weight is 100 kilograms (220 lb). This species is important commercially and is also popular as a game fish. It is threatened by the pressures that these activities put upon the population.[2]

References[edit]

  1. ^ Ntakimazi, G. 2006. Lates angustifrons. In: IUCN 2013. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2013.2. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 24 December 2013.
  2. ^ Froese, Rainer and Pauly, Daniel, eds. (2013). "Lates angustifrons" in FishBase. October 2013 version.
This Perciformes article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

  • t
  • e

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Juveniles live in a specific inshore habitat until they reach 18 cm (Ref. 2216) also found near and in slow flowing affluents (Ref. 36901). Adults found from the littoral to near the limit of the oxygenated zone (Ref. 2216). Solitary, lurking predator, probably favoring rocky bottoms and unspecialized in its fish diet; highly susceptible to intensive fishing (Ref. 2216). Feeds largely on benthic cichlids (Ref. 4967, 36901), but also takes sardines (Ref. 4967). Threatened due to over harvesting (Ref. 58490).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Africa: endemic to Lake Tanganyika (Ref. 2216, 36901), widely distributed throughout the lake (Ref. 36901).
dataObjects.references: Poll, M. 1953 Exploration hydrobiologique du lac Tanganika (1946-1947). Poissons non Cichlidae. Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique, Bruxelles. 251 pp. (Ref. 36901)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 200 cm SL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 4967)); max. published weight: 100.0 kg (Ref. 58490)
references: Eccles, D.H. 1992 FAO species identification sheets for fishery purposes. Field guide to the freshwater fishes of Tanzania. Prepared and published with the support of the United Nations Development Programme (project URT/87/016). FAO, Rome. 145 p. (Ref. 4967)
Stone, R. 2007 The last of the leviathans. Science 316:1684-1688. (Ref. 58490)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Spacing between dorsal fins more than between last spines of first dorsal fin.  Caudal fin rounded in adults, rounded and spotted in juveniles.  Eyes small, less than interorbital with.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Environment
dataObjects.description: demersal; freshwater; pH range: 7.5 - 8.2; dH range: 20 - 40

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TrophicStrategy
dataObjects.description: Adults are common in inshore areas;  occupy deep, rock ground as they grow  larger. Also sedentary and solitary. Aggregate while hunting for clupeid prey in pelagic zones, migrating up nightly from the bottom (Ref. 52862).
